<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Strava---App">Strava - App<a class="anchor-link" href="#Strava---App">¶</a></h1><p>Stravapp is a lot of things. I'll try to give an objective account of them before I say anything personal about the project.</p>
<p><strong>links:</strong></p>
<p><strong>production: </strong><a href="https://www.stravapp.herokuapp.com">project</a>,
<a href="https://github.com/lgoerl/stravapp">github</a></p>
<p><strong>tutorials: </strong><a href="http://www.quasicoherentlabs.com/blog/setting-up-a-postgresql-rds-on-amazon-aws">part 1</a>,
<a href="http://www.quasicoherentlabs.com/blog/connecting-a-flask-controlled-app-to-our-postgres-database">part 2</a>,
<a href="http://www.quasicoherentlabs.com/blog/constructing-an-angular-front-end-for-a-flask-app">part 3</a>,
<a href="https://lgoerl.github.io/stravapp-part4">part 4</a></p>
<h2 id="Readme.md">Readme.md<a class="anchor-link" href="#Readme.md">¶</a></h2><p>Stravapp is a tool built by <a href="http://www.bryanbischof.com">Bryan Bischof</a>, Jeff Larson, and myself to implement some of the features we wanted to use with <a href="http://www.strava.com">Strava</a>'s user-created routes. Routes, if you're not familiar, are a fairly underdeveloped content-type provided by Strava's platform, allowing the user to create a predetermined route, utilizing Strava's segments, or not. They can be made private or public, but there is really no way to search for them. Currently, there have been 7million + routes created by Strava's users - and it seemed like a totally natural thing to make them searchable in some way.</p>
<p>This is, essentially, what we've done: make them searchable. From our app, these routes can be queried by a variety of parameters, including location. We're currently in the process of making location based queries much more accessible with location based parameters by reverse-geocoding each route by the latitude and longitude coordinates included for starting and ending locations for each route with <a href="https://github.com/thampiman/reverse-geocoder">reverse-geocoder</a>. From this we'll be able to add meta-data such as state and county level columns to our dataset.</p>
<p>To implement this feature, we first scraped and cleaned the data from Strava's website. The initial 10,000 routes are all that have been copied to the production database. This step of the project was done by Jeff and Bryan. We are currently in the process of automating the scraping, cleaning, and extraction of location data with <code>reverse-geocoder</code> for the remaining 7million routes. His progress can be seen in his repo <a href="https://github.com/BBischof/strava-route_grabber">strava-route_grabber</a>. A very cool aspect that I'm excited to see is the implementation of this process on a distributed system, which he's currently working on. (Although, as of yet, we have not been rate-limited by Strava's servers).</p>
<h4 id="Front-end">Front-end<a class="anchor-link" href="#Front-end">¶</a></h4><p>The data is stored in an Amazon PostgreSQL RDS that acts as the foundation of the <code>flask</code>-based back-end. We've used <code>flask_restful</code> to setup an API that parses dynamic endpoint queries from users and the front-end. The back-end uses</p>
<ul>
<li>flask, Blueprint,</li>
<li>flask_restful,</li>
<li>flask_sqlalchemy,</li>
<li>marshmallow.</li>
</ul>
<h4 id="Back-end">Back-end<a class="anchor-link" href="#Back-end">¶</a></h4><p>The front-end is all done in AngularJS, and the UI is all done within the framework of <code>Angular-Material</code>. Error and warning messages are displayed with <code>toaster</code> and queries are all displayed in a <code>ui-grid</code>. Dependencies include</p>
<ul>
<li>ngResource</li>
<li>ngMaterial</li>
<li>ui-grid</li>
<li>ui-router, stateProvider</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="Personal-take-aways-and-difficulties">Personal take-aways and difficulties<a class="anchor-link" href="#Personal-take-aways-and-difficulties">¶</a></h2><p>There's no getting around it, this project has been difficult for me for several reasons. Most obviously, I only had a basic grasp of <code>flask</code> when this project started, but had exactly  experience with any of the other tools utilized, or even with javascript, for the most part, let alone Angular. These frustrations are inevitable but temporary - and reduced by the fact that I like learning things anyway. This did make the project take longer than it would have otherwise, both due to the lack of familiarity with the language, but also with the app/project structures. And, also, because I was the only one working on it after the initial round of data had been scraped and cleaned.</p>
<p>Another frustration was scope-creep, which definitely interacted with being the only one working on the project.</p>
<p>Despite (or, in result of?) the difficulties of the project, I ended up learning a lot. I think, most valuably (in addition to the coding with flask and angular), I got a good taste of developing in a test/production style environment with the help of git, and working with a product manager to set goals and scope things out before digging into technical tasks. The latter is something I've had experience with in grad school, but it's something that I'll probably need to keep learning.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<h1 id="Part-IV---Querying-the-Database">Part IV - Querying the Database<a class="anchor-link" href="#Part-IV---Querying-the-Database">¶</a></h1><p><a href="http://www.quasicoherentlabs.com/blog/setting-up-a-postgresql-rds-on-amazon-aws">Part 1 - Setting up a PostgreSQL RDS with Amazon's AWS</a></p>
<p><a href="http://www.quasicoherentlabs.com/blog/connecting-a-flask-controlled-app-to-our-postgres-database">Part 2 - Flask: building a RESTFUL API over the PostgreSQL RDS</a></p>
<p><a href="http://www.quasicoherentlabs.com/blog/constructing-an-angular-front-end-for-a-flask-app">Part 3 - The Front-End, with AngularJS</a></p>
<p><a href="https://github.com/lgoerl/stravapp">github</a></p>
<p>Techinically, parts I-III have already setup a query of the database - albeit, a trivial one. In this entry, we'll add the functionality to allow users to specify some more complicated queries. This is a good time to make a new <code>git</code> branch so that you don't mess up your master. Something like <code>git checkout -b form-query</code> will do. Now, before we start, let's quickly recall what we're working with, and what we'll add:</p>
<pre><code>project
│   app.py
│   procfile
│   requirements.txt
│   .env
│
└───static
│   │   app.js
│   │
│   └───partials
│       │   list.html
│   
└───templates
    │   index.html</code></pre>
<h3 id="app.py"><em>app.py</em><a class="anchor-link" href="#app.py">¶</a></h3><h4 id="contains">contains<a class="anchor-link" href="#contains">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li><code>SQLAlchemy</code> db model for <code>courses</code> SQL table</li>
<li><code>flask_restful</code> api resource class with <code>get</code> method for querying the database</li>
<li>Initialization of <code>api</code> and <code>Blueprint</code>s for setting the route prefixes for the api</li>
<li><code>marshmallow</code> schema for dumping query results</li>
<li><code>flask</code> route for rendering the index page</li>
</ul>
<h4 id="to-add">to add<a class="anchor-link" href="#to-add">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li>a new <code>flask_restful</code> api resource for parsing the query endpoint</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="html"><em>html</em><a class="anchor-link" href="#html">¶</a></h3><h4 id="contains">contains<a class="anchor-link" href="#contains">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li>index.html with a single element to grab the first entries in the database</li>
<li>list.html corresponding to the <code>AngularJS</code> state which will display the query results</li>
</ul>
<h4 id="to-add">to add<a class="anchor-link" href="#to-add">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li>form.html which will contain input elements by which the user can specify a query</li>
</ul>
<h3 id="app.js"><em>app.js</em><a class="anchor-link" href="#app.js">¶</a></h3><h4 id="contains">contains<a class="anchor-link" href="#contains">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li>resource factory that will <code>get</code> the static query we've defined</li>
<li>definition of states for initial index view and query display view</li>
<li>controller for sending the query results to the DOM</li>
</ul>
<h4 id="to-add">to add<a class="anchor-link" href="#to-add">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li>new resource factory to interact with the new api resource we will be defining in the <code>app.py</code></li>
<li>new controller pass query parameters from the form DOM to the back end api</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="The-Form">The Form<a class="anchor-link" href="#The-Form">¶</a></h2><p>Let's start with making the form by which users will specify query parameters. We'll add some basic filters for total distance covered and total elevation change, and then a more complex filter for a starting and ending location.</p>
<p><code>cd</code> into your project folder (which should trigger the activation of your virtual environment -- if not, activate it) and make the partial for the form: <code>touch /static/partials/form.html</code>. Since it's a partial, it's rendered within the <code>index.html</code> and we don't have to load any css or script assets. That said, I'm going to use <code>Angular</code>'s <code>Material</code>, so that things look as pretty as possible, while still being lazy. That means loading some scripts into the index page. Add the following to <code>index.html</code>:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">link</span> <span class="na">rel</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"stylesheet"</span> <span class="na">href</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular-material/1.1.3/angular-material.min.css"</span><span class="p">></span>
<span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"https://code.angularjs.org/1.5.5/angular-animate.min.js"</span><span class="p">><!--</span--><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">></span>
<span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular-material/1.1.3/angular-material.min.js"</span><span class="p">><!--</span--><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">></span>
<span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">script</span> <span class="na">src</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/angular.js/1.5.5/angular-aria.min.js"</span><span class="p">><!--</span--><span class="nt">script</span><span class="p">></span>
</pre></div>
<p>In the <code>form.html</code> we then need to use material's <code><md-input container></code> to wrap the input elements. We'll also need to specify a container within the AngularJS <code>app.js</code> that will house the data before passing it to the backend. <code>appForm</code> will be the json container housing all the information and functions relevant to <code>form.html</code> -- which may be a surprising number of things when all is said and done. Containing the form data, we'll use <code>appForm.data</code> as the container for the data; it will have elements corresponding to the parameters we're passing from the input form. Recall our table has columns for <code>length_in_meters</code> and <code>elevation_gain_in_meters</code>; to search within a range of values for each, we'll need <code>min</code> and <code>max</code> parameters. Note that specifying <code>type=number</code> in the input elements saves us the trouble of varifying the datatype being passed, because it won't allow anything other than numerical entries.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">form</span> <span class="na">ng-submit</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"appForm.submit()"</span><span class="p">></span>>
<span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">md-content</span> <span class="na">layout-gt-sm</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"row"</span> <span class="na">layout-padding</span><span class="p">></span>
<span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">></span>
  <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">span</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"md-headline"</span><span class="p">></span>Distance the route covers:<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">span</span><span class="p">><</span><span class="nt">br</span><span class="p">></span>
    <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">md-input-container</span><span class="p">></span>
      <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">></span>minimum<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">></span>
      <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"number"</span> <span class="na">ng-model</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"appForm.data.dist_min"</span><span class="p">></span>
    <span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">md-input-container</span><span class="p">></span>
    <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">md-input-container</span><span class="p">></span>
      <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">></span>maximum<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">></span>
      <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"number"</span> <span class="na">ng-model</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"appForm.data.dist_max"</span><span class="p">></span>
    <span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">md-input-container</span><span class="p">></span> 
    <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">br</span><span class="p">></span>

  <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">span</span> <span class="na">class</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"md-headline"</span><span class="p">></span>Total elevation change along the route:<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">span</span><span class="p">><</span><span class="nt">br</span><span class="p">></span>
    <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">md-input-container</span><span class="p">></span>
      <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">></span>minimum<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">></span>
      <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"number"</span> <span class="na">ng-model</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"appForm.data.elev_min"</span><span class="p">></span>
    <span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">md-input-container</span><span class="p">></span>
    <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">md-input-container</span><span class="p">></span>
      <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">></span>maximum<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">label</span><span class="p">></span>
      <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"number"</span> <span class="na">ng-model</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">"appForm.data.elev_max"</span><span class="p">></span>
    <span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">md-input-container</span><span class="p">></span>

  <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">'button'</span> <span class="na">value</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">'Reset'</span> <span class="na">ng-click</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">'appForm.reset()'</span> <span class="p">/></span>
  <span class="p"><</span><span class="nt">input</span> <span class="na">type</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s">'submit'</span><span class="p">/><</span><span class="nt">br</span><span class="p">></span>

<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">div</span><span class="p">></span>
<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">md-content</span><span class="p">></span>
<span class="p"><!--</span--><span class="nt">form</span><span class="p">></span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The above will give you input elements to specify min and max values for distance and elevation gain, along with submission and forms clearing buttons (which, you'll notice, reference functions that we'll have to define). This is a good time to try the code out and make sure everything is rendering. Recall that you can do this in your console by running <code>python app.py</code> and navigating your browser to <code>localhost:5000</code>. Speaking of good times, this is also a good time to commit/push your changes to your new branch.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="passing-data">passing data<a class="anchor-link" href="#passing-data">¶</a></h2><p>Now that the form itself is created, we know that we're querying by 4 numeric parameters: <code>dist_min</code>, <code>dist_max</code>, <code>elev_min</code>, and <code>elev_max</code>. <code>flask_restful</code> has a built-in way to setup a CRUD, but since I was only setting this up to query, I used a dynamic endpoint that can parse query parameters, and that's what I'm going to cover here. The query will be specified similarly to the way it is already done, by hitting <code>your-heroku-app.herokuapp.com/api/v1/courses.json</code>, except now we want to pass parameters from the url. A query will look like <code>your-heroku-app.herokuapp.com/api/v1/courses/dist_min=10&dist;_max=50&elev;_max=800.json</code>. (you can choose to include the <code>.json</code> suffix at your leisure, but be consitent).</p>
<h4 id="the-resource-factory-(app.js)">the resource factory (app.js)<a class="anchor-link" href="#the-resource-factory-(app.js)">¶</a></h4><p>This factory is, oddly, very similar to the previous one. Instead of allowing for an <code>id</code> to be passed to the api, we will pass an <code>endpoint</code>. The rest is the same. The factory looks like</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">factory</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'queryFactory'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$resource</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="p">{</span>
  <span class="k">return</span> <span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$resource</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'api/v2/courses/query/:endpoint.json'</span><span class="p">,</span> 
    <span class="p">{</span> <span class="nx">endpoint</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="s1">'@endpoint'</span> <span class="p">},</span> 
    <span class="p">{</span> <span class="s1">'query'</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="nx">method</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">'GET'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">isArray</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">true</span> <span class="p">}},</span>
    <span class="p">{</span> <span class="nx">update</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="nx">method</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="s1">'PATCH'</span> <span class="p">}},</span> 
    <span class="p">{</span> <span class="nx">stripTrailingSlashes</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kc">false</span> <span class="p">}</span>
    <span class="p">);</span>
</pre></div>
<h4 id="the-form-controller-(app.js)">the form controller (app.js)<a class="anchor-link" href="#the-form-controller-(app.js)">¶</a></h4><p>This controller will get the data submitted from the form and use it to call the <code>get</code> that we defined in the Angular resource factory above. First, make the <code>appForm.data</code> container for the form inputs we specified in the <code>form.html</code>. Then, we need to turn this json blurb/dictionary into a string of the form <code>dist_min=10&dist;_max=50&elev;_max=800</code> - this is called <em>serialization</em>, and can be done using the function <code>httpParamSerializerJQLike</code> (which depends on <code>http</code>), so we'll have to load both of these when declaring dependencies in the controller definition. This function will take all the attributes of a json blurb and serialized them in the form above: <code>att_1=val_1&...&att;_n=val_n</code>. To keep it from passing <code>null</code> values, we'll have to write a little script to find the non-null attributes - it's really just an iteration on the keys of the <code>appForm.data</code> element with an <code>if</code> statement. This will all be contained in the function <code>submit</code> that is called when the submission button on the form is activated.</p>
<p>Delete the old controller and start over. Everything to do with the form will be in the <code>formController</code>.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="nx">angular</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">module</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'myApp.Controllers'</span><span class="p">,[])</span>
<span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">controller</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"formController"</span><span class="p">,[</span><span class="s2">"$state"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"$scope"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"$http"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"$httpParamSerializerJQLike"</span><span class="p">,</span> 
  <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$state</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$scope</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$http</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$httpParamSerializerJQLike</span><span class="p">){</span>
    <span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$scope</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appForm</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
      <span class="nx">data</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span>
        <span class="nx">dist_min</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="nx">dist_max</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="nx">elev_min</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="nx">elev_max</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">null</span>
      <span class="p">},</span>
      <span class="nx">cleared</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="p">{</span>
        <span class="nx">dist_min</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="nx">dist_max</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="nx">elev_min</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">null</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="nx">elev_max</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="kc">null</span>
      <span class="p">},</span>
      <span class="nx">submit</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(){</span>
        <span class="nx">nonz</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{};</span>
        <span class="nx">keys</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">Object</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">keys</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$scope</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appForm</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">data</span><span class="p">);</span>
        <span class="k">for</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">k</span> <span class="k">in</span> <span class="nx">keys</span><span class="p">){</span>
          <span class="k">if</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$scope</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appForm</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">keys</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">k</span><span class="p">]]){</span>
            <span class="nx">nonz</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">keys</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">k</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$scope</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appForm</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">keys</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="nx">k</span><span class="p">]];</span> 
          <span class="p">}</span>
        <span class="p">}</span>
        <span class="nx">endpoint</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$httpParamSerializerJQLike</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nx">nonz</span><span class="p">);</span>
        <span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$state</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">go</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'routes.query'</span><span class="p">,{</span><span class="nx">end</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="nx">endpoint</span><span class="p">},</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="nx">reload</span><span class="o">:</span><span class="s1">'routes.query'</span><span class="p">});</span>
      <span class="p">},</span>
      <span class="nx">reset</span><span class="o">:</span> <span class="kd">function</span><span class="p">(){</span>
        <span class="nx">angular</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">copy</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="err">\</span><span class="nx">$scope</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appForm</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">cleared</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nx">$scope</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">appForm</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">data</span><span class="p">);}</span>
    <span class="p">}</span>
<span class="p">}]);</span>
</pre></div>
<p><em>obviously, ignore the backslashes in the above code. Markdown cells will not render them within javascript codeblocks</em></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="the-api-resource">the api resource<a class="anchor-link" href="#the-api-resource">¶</a></h4><p>Just like the super simple query, we'll define a class inheriting from <code>db.Model</code> and a <code>get</code> method for it. This time the <code>get</code> will be more complicated, since it will have to parse <code>dist_min=10&dist;_max=50&elev;_max=800</code>, and things like it. To <code>get</code> will be passed the <code>custom_input</code> generated by Angular from the <code>form.html</code> inputs - we will make it look like the above.</p>
<p>Users will be able to access the api through the url, since that's how the front end does it, so we want to make sure that there are some precautions in place keeping bad queries from being passed. First we'll make sure that incoming queries have the proper parameters -- checking the datatypes of passed values will be done by the <code>db.Model</code>.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="k">class</span> <span class="nc">customQuery</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Resource</span><span class="p">):</span>

    <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">get</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="bp">self</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">custom_input</span><span class="p">):</span>
        <span class="n">custom_input</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">custom_input</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'&'</span><span class="p">)</span>
        <span class="c1">#make a dictionary whose keys are parameter names and values are passed values</span>
        <span class="n">params</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{}</span>
        <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">custom_input</span><span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'='</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'='</span><span class="p">)[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>
        <span class="c1">#check for invalid parameters passed by the user through the endpoint url</span>
        <span class="n">invalids</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">keys</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">set</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="s1">'dist_max'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'dist_min'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'elev_max'</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="s1">'elev_min'</span><span class="p">])]</span>
        <span class="k">if</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="n">invalids</span><span class="p">:</span>    
            <span class="n">q</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">Routes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">query</span>
            <span class="k">try</span><span class="p">:</span> 
                <span class="c1">#try adding the parameters as filters to the query. filters can be added recursively.</span>
                <span class="k">if</span> <span class="s1">'dist_min'</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">keys</span><span class="p">():</span>
                    <span class="n">q</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">q</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">filter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Routes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">length_in_meters</span><span class="o">>=</span><span class="nb">float</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dist_min'</span><span class="p">]))</span>
                <span class="k">if</span> <span class="s1">'dist_max'</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">keys</span><span class="p">():</span>
                    <span class="n">q</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">q</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">filter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Routes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">length_in_meters</span><span class="o"><=</span><span class="nb">float</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'dist_max'</span><span class="p">]))</span>
                <span class="k">if</span> <span class="s1">'elev_min'</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">keys</span><span class="p">():</span>
                    <span class="n">q</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">q</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">filter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Routes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">elevation_gain_in_meters</span><span class="o">>=</span><span class="nb">float</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'elev_min'</span><span class="p">]))</span>
                <span class="k">if</span> <span class="s1">'elev_max'</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">params</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">keys</span><span class="p">():</span>
                    <span class="n">q</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">q</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">filter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">Routes</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">elevation_gain_in_meters</span><span class="o"><=</span><span class="nb">float</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">params</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'elev_max'</span><span class="p">]))</span>
            <span class="k">except</span> <span class="ne">ValueError</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="n">err</span><span class="p">:</span>
                <span class="n">resp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">jsonify</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s2">"error"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="n">err</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">message</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"status_code"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">403</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"links"</span><span class="p">:{</span><span class="s2">"error"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="bp">True</span><span class="p">}})</span>
                <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">resp</span>

            <span class="n">results_query</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">q</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">limit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">100</span><span class="p">)</span>
            <span class="n">results</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">schema</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dump</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">results_query</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">many</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="bp">True</span><span class="p">)</span>

        <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
            <span class="n">resp</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">jsonify</span><span class="p">({</span><span class="s2">"error"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="s2">"You have specified the following invalid search parameters: {}."</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">', '</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">join</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">invalids</span><span class="p">)),</span> <span class="s2">"status_code"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">204</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"links"</span><span class="p">:{</span><span class="s2">"error"</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="bp">True</span><span class="p">}})</span>
            <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">resp</span>
</pre></div>
<p>Now all that we need to do is add the resource to the api with a specified endpoint with the following line.</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="n">api</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">add_resource</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">queryRoutes</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'/<custom_input>.json'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">endpoint</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'api/v1/courses/query'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="Routing-and-stating">Routing and stating<a class="anchor-link" href="#Routing-and-stating">¶</a></h3><p>The next thing that we need to do is make sure that states exist to display the query form by default. This is done in the <code>courses</code> state by simply by replacing a the <code>template</code> line with <code>templateUrl: '../static/partials/form.html'</code></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Finally, make sure that you've added all the dependencies to your intitialization statement! This is something I had problems with numerous times, and it was super frustrating! Also, check and make sure that everything that needs scripts and css files loaded, gets loaded in the <code>index.html</code> - also super frustrating. In the <code>app.js</code> your initialization should look like</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="kd">var</span> <span class="nx">app</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nx">angular</span><span class="p">.</span><span class="nx">module</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'myApp'</span><span class="p">,[</span><span class="s1">'ui.router'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'ngResource'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'myApp.Services'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'myApp.Controllers'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'ngAria'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'ngAnimate'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'ngMaterial'</span><span class="p">]);</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This is a big commit, and almost <em>has</em> to be done that way, since no piece will work without the others. Test your app as often as you can (again, problematic here) and commit often as well.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Again, this project is still in development. Code can be found on my <a href="https://github.com/lgoerl/stravapp">github</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<script type="text/javascript">if (!document.getElementById('mathjaxscript_pelican_#%@#$@#')) {
    var mathjaxscript = document.createElement('script');
    mathjaxscript.id = 'mathjaxscript_pelican_#%@#$@#';
    mathjaxscript.type = 'text/javascript';
    mathjaxscript.src = '//cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS-MML_HTMLorMML';
    mathjaxscript[(window.opera ? "innerHTML" : "text")] =
        "MathJax.Hub.Config({" +
        "    config: ['MMLorHTML.js']," +
        "    TeX: { extensions: ['AMSmath.js','AMSsymbols.js','noErrors.js','noUndefined.js'], equationNumbers: { autoNumber: 'AMS' } }," +
        "    jax: ['input/TeX','input/MathML','output/HTML-CSS']," +
        "    extensions: ['tex2jax.js','mml2jax.js','MathMenu.js','MathZoom.js']," +
        "    displayAlign: 'center'," +
        "    displayIndent: '0em'," +
        "    showMathMenu: true," +
        "    tex2jax: { " +
        "        inlineMath: [ ['$','$'] ], " +
        "        displayMath: [ ['$$','$$'] ]," +
        "        processEscapes: true," +
        "        preview: 'TeX'," +
        "    }, " +
        "    'HTML-CSS': { " +
        " linebreaks: { automatic: true, width: '95% container' }, " +
        "        styles: { '.MathJax_Display, .MathJax .mo, .MathJax .mi, .MathJax .mn': {color: 'black ! important'} }" +
        "    } " +

    (document.body || document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0]).appendChild(mathjaxscript);
}

div.cell {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  border-radius: 2px;
  box-sizing: border-box;
  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;
  -webkit-box-sizing: border-box;
  border-width: 1px;
  border-style: solid;
  border-color: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  padding: 5px;
  /* This acts as a spacer between cells, that is outside the border */
  margin: 0px;
  outline: none;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, transparent -40px, transparent 1px, transparent 1px, transparent 100%);
}
div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-left-color: #90CAF9;
  border-left-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  border-right-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-right-width: 1px;
  background: #E3F2FD;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
div.cell.selected {
  border-color: #ababab;
  border-left-width: 0px;
  padding-left: 6px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, #42A5F5 -40px, #42A5F5 5px, transparent 5px, transparent 100%);
}
@media print {
  div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-left-width: 0;
  padding-left: 6px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, #42A5F5 -40px, #42A5F5 7px, #E3F2FD 7px, #E3F2FD 100%);
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected {
  border-color: #66BB6A;
  border-left-width: 0px;
  padding-left: 6px;
  background: linear-gradient(to right, #66BB6A -40px, #66BB6A 5px, transparent 5px, transparent 100%);
}
@media print {
  .edit_mode div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}

    text-align: left;
  }
}

  min-width: 0;

  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;

  -moz-box-flex: 1;

/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: #f7f7f7;
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is
   to make sure that empty JavaScript output_subareas have no height. */
div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}
div.unrecognized_cell {
  padding: 5px 5px 5px 0px;

}

/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;
 * }
 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;
  overflow-x: auto;
}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  padding: 0.4em;
}
.CodeMirror-linenumber {
  padding: 0 8px 0 4px;
}
.CodeMirror-gutters {
  border-bottom-left-radius: 2px;
  border-top-left-radius: 2px;
}
.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. We need the 0 value because of how we size */
  /* .CodeMirror-lines */
  padding: 0;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;
}

div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}

div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;

  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;

  display: box;

}

}

.output {

  display: -moz-box;

    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */

div.output_area pre {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  border: 0;
  vertical-align: baseline;
  color: black;
  background-color: transparent;
  border-radius: 0;
}
/* This class is for the output subarea inside the output_area and after
   the prompt div. */
div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: auto;
  padding: 0.4em;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
  max-width: calc(100% - 14ex);
}
div.output_scroll div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: visible;
}
/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different
   output types */
/* all text output has this class: */
div.output_text {

  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */

/* Empty output_javascript divs should have no height */

  padding: 0em 0.25em;

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="The-Myth-of-Clean-Coal">The Myth of Clean Coal<a class="anchor-link" href="#The-Myth-of-Clean-Coal">¶</a></h1><h4 id="links">links<a class="anchor-link" href="#links">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li><a href="https://github.com/BBischof/suncode-hackathon">github</a> </li>
<li><a href="https://devpost.com/software/clean-coal-ljti0z">devpost</a></li>
</ul>
<p>  This weekend (Friday and Saturday, April 8th) I participated in <a href="https://suncode2017.devpost.com/">Powerhouse's SunCode 2017 Hackathon</a> in a team of 5: engineers Bryan Bischof and Jeff Larson, and industry professionals Caroline Whittinghill and Geoff Cotter. To moderate amusement and confusion of the rest of the room, we named ourselves CLEAN COAL - you know, the joke. This was my first hackathon, so I didn't really have any expectations, but to save you the suspense, I did leave pretty disappointed. Also, exhausted, smelly, and very dehydrated.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>   Powerhouse's sponsors for the event, <a href="https://www.dsm.com/corporate/about/business-entities/dsm-venturing.html">DSM</a> and <a href="https://www.sunrun.com/">Sunrun</a> both issued two of their own challenges, and Powerhouse issued one, which can be found on the event page above. Many teams came up with really creative projects to work on outside the scope of these challenges -- one team attempted to develop a completely novel power generation process using gravitational wave! -- and I believe 3rd place and honerable mentions were won by such teams, but the real money went to teams that addressed the challenges put forth by the judges, as did we.</p>
<p>   Our team tackled Powerhouse's challenge. Put in their own words:</p>
<h4 id=""-Batteries-are-being-installed-at-a-rapid-rate-as-part-of-solar-systems.-Create-an-algorithm-or-machine-learning-routine-that-will-maximize-customer-benefit-in-a-variable-TOU-rate-situation-while-also-maximizing-battery-lifespan.--"">" Batteries are being installed at a rapid rate as part of solar systems. Create an algorithm or machine learning routine that will maximize customer benefit in a variable TOU rate situation while also maximizing battery lifespan.  "<a class="anchor-link" href="#"-Batteries-are-being-installed-at-a-rapid-rate-as-part-of-solar-systems.-Create-an-algorithm-or-machine-learning-routine-that-will-maximize-customer-benefit-in-a-variable-TOU-rate-situation-while-also-maximizing-battery-lifespan.--"">¶</a></h4><p>This challenge easily showcased our teams talents and skillset the best out of the five, and seemed legitimately interesting. Though it was against the rules to code anything before the event officially started on Firday evening, since we had a team made up before the event and decided on a challenge, we met a few days early and had Caroline and Josh melt our faces off with a bombardment of technical jargon. That night we laid down an approach that would end up utilizing more data than we actually could during the competition -- which isn't that surprising.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><img alt="Clean Coal model" src="https://lgoerl.github.io/images/sunrun_model.jpg" /></p>
<h4 id="Approach">Approach<a class="anchor-link" href="#Approach">¶</a></h4><p>   Our (super optimistic) goal is pictured in the above diagram. In words, we're making a controller to decide when to charge and discharge the batteries, and where to send the power when they are discharged. 
We would build two daily forecasters:</p>
<ul>
<li>one for energy demand, and </li>
<li>one for production from a PhotoVoltaic installation. 
We'd also have data on battery usage, which we would use to build a model for battery life and usage*. </li>
</ul>
<p>   Power from the grid must be paid for, and the price is determined by the Time Of Use plan used by the power company. Generally, power is more expensive during the day, during peak hours, and less expensive at other times. The algorithm will be optimized both to save the most money by utilizing stored power from the batteries during the day and charging them during the off-peak hours, while also avoiding putting undue stress on the batteries to prolong life as long as possible.</p>
<p>*This model is to address the fact that batteries' maximum charge capacity degrades over time, depending on charge and discharge rates, and charge/discharge cycles, while may be at odds with optimized use practices if only considering saving money by discharing during the peak TOU periods.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="In-reality">In reality<a class="anchor-link" href="#In-reality">¶</a></h4><p>   Unfortunately we couldn't actually implement everything in our plan, as should be expected. Problems we encountered mostly boiled down to not having enough time. Though we also couldn't find some of the data re: batteries that we expected to find. We did, however, find some estimated degredation models.</p>
<p>   In the end, we only got a naive model completed. But, due to the testing we did, it worked and didn't leave us with nothing. It even saved a little money on some of the test cases for which we did have data, over not using any battery power at all. This was despite the fact that we only had them charging during PV over-production, which in itself is a pretty uncommon occurance, especially in commercial applications.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="What-I-contributed">What I contributed<a class="anchor-link" href="#What-I-contributed">¶</a></h4><ul>
<li>implemented the function to map timestamps to the corresponding TOU plan rate</li>
<li>helped with development, coding, and trouble-shooting/debugging the controller algorithm</li>
<li>wrote tests for the algorithm</li>
<li>some auxillary helper functions</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 id="Final-thoughts">Final thoughts<a class="anchor-link" href="#Final-thoughts">¶</a></h4><p>   At the start of the entry, you'll remember I said that I was a little disappointed. This is because the winning team (\$4000, and a company, maybe?) was effectively the only other team that attempted the same challenge. They didn't have a controller built, but they had done a better job presenting the idea to the judges by framing the software as a monetizable product, and by giving estimates of how much its implementation would save a customer. There was no need for proof of concept, as there are several companies attempting to provide such a product, and though we didn't have an estimate of saved costs since our algorithm was so naive, we could have done more research on those companies and used their estimates for customer savings. It's frustrating to have gone into it knowing that such an aspect would be emphasized in the judgement of the pitches, and I felt like just another out-of-touch engineer or math nerd getting lost in the details until it was too late to even weild my depleted brain-power thinking of such a simple approach to obtaining this estimate (our plan was to get an estimate from the actual performance of the algorithm, which was too naive to provide anything more than $200/yr in savings -- obviously negligible for a commercial entity).</p>
<p>   Despite being shown up at our own game by another team - the winning team, granted - the event was a lot of fun. My team was filled with badasses, and just plain cool people, and I feel very lucky to have had the opportunity to hang out with those people, but especially in a space wherein we could collaborate on solving a super interesting problem. Caroline and Geoff said they felt useless, but there are no doubts from the developer side that we would not have been able to make anything coherent or appropriate in any way without their help.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>

div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}
/* This class is the outer container of all output sections. */
div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.output_area .MathJax_Display {
  text-align: left !important;
}
div.output_area 
div.output_area 
div.output_area img,
div.output_area svg {
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}
div.output_area img.unconfined,
div.output_area svg.unconfined {
  max-width: none;
}
/* This is needed to protect the pre formating from global settings such
   as that of bootstrap */
.output {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.output_area {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
div.output_area pre {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  border: 0;
  vertical-align: baseline;
  color: black;
  background-color: transparent;
  border-radius: 0;
}
/* This class is for the output subarea inside the output_area and after
   the prompt div. */
div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: auto;
  padding: 0.4em;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
  max-width: calc(100% - 14ex);
}
div.output_scroll div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: visible;
}
/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different
   output types */
/* all text output has this class: */
div.output_text {
  text-align: left;
  color: #000;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */
div.output_stderr {
  background: #fdd;
  /* very light red background for stderr */
}
div.output_latex {
  text-align: left;
}
/* Empty output_javascript divs should have no height */
div.output_javascript:empty {
  padding: 0;
}
.js-error {
  color: darkred;
}
/* raw_input styles */
div.raw_input_container {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  padding-top: 5px;
}
pre.raw_input_prompt {
  /* nothing needed here. */
}
input.raw_input {
  font-family: monospace;
  font-size: inherit;
  color: inherit;
  width: auto;
  /* make sure input baseline aligns with prompt */
  vertical-align: baseline;
  /* padding + margin = 0.5em between prompt and cursor */
  padding: 0em 0.25em;
  margin: 0em 0.25em;
}
input.raw_input:focus {
  box-shadow: none;
}
p.p-space {
  margin-bottom: 10px;
}
div.output_unrecognized {
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
}
div.output_unrecognized a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.output_unrecognized a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}

  color: #000;

}

}


.rendered_html pre,

.rendered_html img,

.rendered_html img.unconfined,

<h2 id="Hello-World!">Hello World!<a class="anchor-link" href="#Hello-World!">¶</a></h2><p><br /></p>
<p>If you haven't gathered from the ubiquitious title, this is my first post.</p>
<p>I hope to use this blog to write about my professional journey, as I make the transition from my previous life in academia to the private sector-- and the world of data science-- and the inevitable personal life events and reflection that happens in between.</p>
</div>
